revised_title: Henley's Experiments on Perpetual Electricity and Electrometers
tldr: In this article, William Henley describes his experiments with a new apparatus called a "machine for exhibiting perpetual electricity." He explores the properties of this device, which consists of a glass plate coated with beeswax and rosin, and a tin-foil coated board. Henley also discusses the behavior of electricity in different materials, such as glass and amber, and the role of electrometers in measuring electrical charges. His findings contribute to the understanding of electricity and its applications.
